title: Vendor Segmentation & Operating Boundaries: How to Run Multi-Vendor AMS Cleanly
hook: Multi-vendor AMS only works when boundaries are real: defined surfaces, measurable contracts, controlled access, and a single arbitration layer.
idea: Modern AMS runs vendors like components in a system. Each vendor owns a surface area with inputs/outputs, SLOs, and evidence rules. Disputes are resolved by timeline + contract, not by politics.

single_prime.description: One prime vendor owns end-to-end AMS; others are subcontractors.
single_prime.best_for: When you want one throat to choke and strong governance exists.
single_prime.risk: Prime may hide root causes or squeeze subs; lock-in increases.

tower_model.description: Vendors split by towers (SAP core, integrations, data, security, infra).
tower_model.best_for: Large landscapes with clear technical separations.
tower_model.risk: Flow issues cross towers; arbitration is mandatory.

flow_pods_model.description: Vendors aligned to business flows (OTC/P2P/RTR) + shared reliability pod.
flow_pods_model.best_for: When business outcomes matter more than module purity.
flow_pods_model.risk: Requires mature flow ownership on the client side.

responsibility_matrix.name: RACI+SLO Map
responsibility_matrix.rule: Every critical flow must have exactly one flow owner.

must_define: What each vendor can change (objects, configs, code zones)
Freeze windows and error budget rules

principles: Every access has intent, owner, and audit trail
practical_controls: Mandatory evidence pack for incident access

dispute_handling.golden_rule: Disputes are resolved by evidence timeline + boundary contract.
workflow: Create a shared incident timeline with evidence IDs
Tag dispute status for monthly settlement (not daily war)

recommended_pricing: Penalties for repeat incidents and change regressions
Credits for demand driver elimination and automation deflection
Shared bonus for cross-vendor systemic fixes
payment_rules: No penalty without evidence pack and validated SLO breach
Separate dependency delay from execution delay
Dispute ledger reviewed monthly with client arbitration

daily: Shared triage with routing by symptom cluster and flow impact
Owner named, next action, next update time
monthly: Scorecard settlement: stability, repeats, regressions, disputes
Boundary tuning: where contracts are unclear
quarterly: Roadmap alignment and lock-in reduction review

metrics_that_make_boundaries_real: Dependency wait time vs execution time
Repeat issues crossing the same boundary

copilot_moves: Auto-attribute incidents to boundaries using signals and objects.
Detect chronic boundary failures and suggest contract updates.

design_question: If two vendors blame each other tomorrow, can we prove responsibility in 10 minutes using contracts and evidence?
